user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_send_iovec_:
```c
ssize_t
MHD_send_iovec_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                 struct MHD_iovec_track_ *const r_iov,
                 bool push_data)
{
#ifdef MHD_VECT_SEND
#if defined(HTTPS_SUPPORT) || \
  defined(_MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED)
  bool use_iov_send = true;
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT || _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
#endif /* MHD_VECT_SEND */

  mhd_assert (NULL != connection->rp.resp_iov.iov);
  mhd_assert (NULL != connection->rp.response->data_iov);
  mhd_assert (connection->rp.resp_iov.cnt > connection->rp.resp_iov.sent);
#ifdef MHD_VECT_SEND
#if defined(HTTPS_SUPPORT) || \
  defined(_MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED)
#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  use_iov_send = use_iov_send &&
                 (0 == (connection->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS));
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
#ifdef _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED
  use_iov_send = use_iov_send && (connection->daemon->sigpipe_blocked ||
                                  connection->sk_spipe_suppress);
#endif /* _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
  if (use_iov_send)
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT || _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
  return send_iov_nontls (connection, r_iov, push_data);
#endif /* MHD_VECT_SEND */

#if ! defined(MHD_VECT_SEND) || defined(HTTPS_SUPPORT) || \
  defined(_MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED)
  return send_iov_emu (connection, r_iov, push_data);
#endif /* !MHD_VECT_SEND || HTTPS_SUPPORT
          || _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I inspected the function for compiler-specific language extensions (examples: GNU/C extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, labels-as-values, asm goto, __extension__, or other documented compiler extensions). None are present in the provided code.

Notes on specific constructs found and why they are not flagged:
- ssize_t: a POSIX type (not a compiler language extension per se). If the project requires strict ISO C without POSIX, this is a portability concern but not a compiler extension per the rule as stated.
- bool: from C99 <stdbool.h> — a standard language feature, not a compiler extension.
- Preprocessor conditionals (#ifdef, #if defined(...), #endif) and backslash line continuations: standard preprocessor use.
- Identifiers with leading underscore (e.g. _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED): these may violate naming conventions or reserved-identifier rules but are not compiler language extensions.

Because none of the recognized compiler-specific extensions appear in the code fragment, there are no suspicious fragments to report for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
